headline: Enchiladas Verdes
description: This enchiladas verdes recipe combines store-bought rotisserie chicken with homemade spicy tomatillo sauce for an easy and delicious weeknight dinner.
name: Enchiladas Verdes
recipeIngredient: 2.25 pounds small green tomatillos, husks removed
0.5 store-bought rotisserie chicken, meat removed and shredded
1 (8 ounce) container Mexican crema, crema fresca

recipeInstructions.text: Cover a large griddle with aluminum foil and preheat to medium-high.

Cook tomatillos, serrano peppers, and garlic on the hot griddle, turning occasionally, until toasted and blackened — about 5 minutes for garlic, 10 minutes for peppers, and 15 minutes for tomatillos. Remove to a bowl and allow to cool.
Heat oil in a small, deep skillet to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Lightly fry tortillas, one at a time, in hot oil until warmed through, 3 to 5 seconds per side. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate.

Place toasted tomatillos, serrano peppers, and garlic in a blender. Add water and blend until smooth; pour into a saucepan over medium heat and bring to a boil. Dissolve chicken bouillon in the mixture, reduce heat, and cook at a simmer until slightly thickened, about 10 minutes.
Soak tortillas in sauce, one at a time, for a few seconds. Fill each tortilla with shredded chicken and sprinkle with sauce. Roll up tortillas and place seam-side down in a serving dish.
Spoon a generous amount of sauce over rolled tortillas. Top with lettuce, cilantro, crema, and cotija cheese. Pour remaining sauce on top or serve on the side.

review.reviewBody: I added onion to the tomatillo sauce.
I love this recipe.. I’m Mexican and it’s really delicious and authentic

I followed the review to spray the tortillas and cook them that way and also to broil tomatillos and peppers. I used GF tortillas. All the rest stayed the same. This meal was delicious!! Whole family loved it!
Delicious!!

I made this according to the recipe. I even went to an Hispanic grocery store to get the ingredients. The presentation was awesome - so pretty! I thought they were good, but only OK - nothing to write home about.
This was amazing! I made it for the first time about a month ago and now it is a regular go to recipe. So easy and delicious!

Yesss! A little time consuming but very authentic. I also broiled my tomatillos instead of grilling. I sometimes can’t find cotija cheese. Feta is adequate in a pinch. I don’t know why the one reviewer said it was rubbery cheese. It’s soft and salty.
I think I will do these as tacos, same ingredients just a little less work with the rolling

These are SENSATIONAL!! Took a bit of a hunt and peck at the grocery store to find some of the ingredients, but find them I did. I made this recipe exactly as written except had to use jalapeño pepper instead of serrano. Not by choice, just all the serrano peppers were gone. (I did remove the seeds to reduce the heat). I also only added half the water as stated for the sauce to speed up the reduction time. SO very good and I had one leftover that I had the next day. I was sure it would be kind gross and soggy. NOT the case! Maybe not as great as day 1, but still super good. The Mexican Crema is very important. Has a big of a sweet cream flavor — unlike sour cream. Can’t wait to make them again for company!!
I don't like chicken enchiladas so I use queso fresco or other Mexican cheese. Otherwise, good recipe.

My family LOVED this
Made just added a little extra cheese inside the tortilla with the chicken.

This was a great recipe! My one and only grocery store was totally out of fresh tomatillos, so I bought a 24oz jar of medium spicy thick salsa verde and substituted it for the garlic, tomatillos, and serranos. I put it in the pan with the water and Better than Bouillon.

This recipe is delicious! I double checked while making as the recipe doesn’t call for any spices and thought maybe I missed something. I didn’t. No spices are needed. The natural flavor of the charred tomatillo and Serrano along with the bouillon is all that’s needed. Love this. Great reviews by the family too!
 I took a pic but the file size was too large to share.
super good! walmart was out of tomatillos so I substituted barely ripe roma tomatoes with lime added
I used green sauce in a can so this inspired me! It was super good.
Excellent recipe. Followed to a T, hubby LOVED them

So, I wasn't able to follow all the instructions perfectly (I don't own a griddle, for example), but it turned out delicious in the end. I only used 1 cup of water, as others suggested, and I liked the thicker sauce. I'd make it again.
I've had enchiladas Verdes from numerous places and it was way more flavorful. it's missing the flavor and the right cheese. This was time-consuming and disappointing.

A+. I’ve never used tomatillos, Serrano peppers or fried tortillas. I’ve never even purchased cojita cheese. So there was a bit of effort for me, but the timing was close. It took me an hour and ten minutes ... and it was worth every single step. So amazing. I would order this in a restaurant and now I don’t have to. So impressed with myself. Thanks so much to the person who shared this. My head is in Old Town Santa Fe right now.

My family loves this dish. I also use 2 cups of water for the sauce, not 3 as called for in the recipe. It makes a thicker sauce and there are no leftovers. One of our favorite meals for a special occasion.
Changed up the recipe a little but came out amazing. Made the sauce the same way but I made taco seasoned shredded chicken and just topped my enchiladas with the sauce and queso Fresca. So good!

I have made this I think 6 times now in the last few months. I'm actually kind of a novice cook but it doesn't at all seem laborious or time-consuming to me. Maybe I was just born to cook Mexican food (I for sure was born to eat it!). :D

Couple notes I'd make:

-I was born in California and grew up eating spicy Mexican food, but 2 whole serranos is plenty (assuming you don't de-seed them). 3 makes it quite a bit more spicy than is comfortable for most people.
-You can easily cut the bouillon in half without losing flavor. Helps to keep the sodium level reasonable.
-I ladle on tons of salsa at every step: drenching the chicken before I roll the enchilada, again on top of the enchilada before I put the other toppings on, and once again over everything, just in case. My plate is swimming in salsa, and it's amazing. (And it still leaves you with tons of leftover salsa for leftovers or chilaquiles the next morning!)
-I've discovered that Greek yogurt works very well as a substitute for crema (similar consistency and tanginess).

I made it today (again!) on lockdown with COVID-19 circulating and so couldn't source cilantro or lettuce. Both really do help with adding flavor and texture, but it was still amazing. :)

Fantastic! My kids and husband ate every bite! Really does taste just as good, if not better than what I’ve had from some authentic Mexican restaurants. Looking to try it with some shredded pork next time!

I made no changes. I loved it. It was as I was hoping. I had never bought tomatillos before so this was my first experience. Roasting on a griddle seemed a little laborious -- I think next time I will actually roast everything in the oven. I had enough sauce leftover to make it a second day. .

The sauce was perfect!! I have always baked my enchiladas but the approach mentioned in this recipe was SO much better. I won’t be eating out as much now that I know how to make enchiladas like this. And my teens loved it!

Super Duper recipe!! It was a bit of work but well worth the effort to have a real authentic Verde sauce. I wanted to skip frying the tortilla step but didn't based on one reviewer saying it was important. It make ALOT of sauce. I didn't use it all as I thought it would be too wet and soupy. Good news, I have extra sauce to do it again!! Also, I'm not sure about the crema being absolutely necessary.....I will try sour cream next time. YUM!!

Made this and absolutely loved it, made a few changes added shredded spicy jack cheese , skipped the Mexican creama and baked it for 15 min. Topped w/fresh avocado & sour cream. Makes great left over w/an egg over easy atop. 
This dish has a great flavor will make again...

This recipe is outstanding! It is the only way I will prepare enchiladas going forward. The flavors were spectacular. 

I did as others suggested and broiled the garlic, tomatillos and peppers. Also reduced water by 1 cup. Other than that, followed the recipe exactly and could not be happier with the outcome. 

Thank you Gema!
We loved it. Although we should have read some of the suggestions, using a griddle, took way to long.
Very messy. But messy is sometimes worth it, this dish is no exception!!! Fairly spicy but when I put refried beans it was pretty tasty. Expect the dish to be flavorful. We likes it....
So easy and oh so delicious. I saved my leftover verde sauce, cooked it, then used it for a spicy gazpacho.
I'm in love with enchiladas and these are my absolute favorite!

I've made this several times; it makes an excellent sauce. I use a grill pan to char the vegetables outside on my gas grill. To avoid the problem of soggy tortillas, mix shredded chicken into the sauce and serve it alongside warm tortillas and toppings for everyone to assemble as they eat. Thanks for sharing.

This was easy and quite delicious. Leftovers disappeared from the fridge overnight! Accompanied with homemade Crema Fresca......1 cup heavy cream, 1 tablespoon buttermilk. Combine in a jar and let sit lightly covered out on your counter overnight. When it starts to thicken, cover tightly and refrigerate until very thick, approx 12 hours. Whisk in a pinch of sea salt and a teaspoon lime juice.

These are very good, although I have to say my family prefers the full fat edition (from this site). The sauce was outstanding! I went to my local Mexican market for their in-store made cojita cheese, to make it true to recipe. I even bought a delicious rotisserie chicken from them. The only things I did differently - I used only 1 cup of water, which was enough to keep the sauce with some thickness. Also, after I wrapped all of the enchiladas, before adding any additional sauce, cheese or crema, I put them in a 400 degree oven for 12 minutes, so I could serve them hot. Then put them on a bed of lettuce, topping them with more sauce, cheese, a little crema, along with cilantro, cheese and avocado. Light and healthy summer's end supper.

I love this recipe! I've made it twice now with a few personal tweaks. I have tried using grilled steak and onions instead of chiken which has turned out SO good. I also like to add a little bit of cornstarch mixed with water to thicken up the verdes sauce. Lastly, I bake the enchiladas after topping with sauce and cheese for 20 minutes at 350 degrees.

Delicious, I had to make some changes, I couldn't find any tomatillos and didnt have time to stop at a mexican grocery, so I bought some enchilada sauce with very little added in, and just kind of wung the rest and it turned out delicious

I love chilaquiles verdes, but I haven't been able to find a good commercial salsa or sauce for the tortilla chips, so I decided to make the sauce.

I added and extra serrano, two extra cloves of gralic, and used a rich chicken stock instead of bouillon and water. It's sitting on the stove cooling now, and I keep going back to taste it. It's that good.

It's not prep intensive, but it is time consuming to roast the vegetables. However, the end result is well worth it, and I look forward to having chilaquiles this weekend.
My family enjoyed this so much! The instructions made this so easy! Will be making this again!
Made it for a casual Sunday dinner. Everyone loved it, had to adjust the heat down to 1 Serrano or it would of been way to hot. Great dish, will definitely make it again!

For the first time in my cooking life, I did not alter one part of this recipe. It is terrific just as it was created. Easy to make and just spicy enough without too much heat. This recipe will go into my permanent file. Serve this to any guests and they will be coming back for more!

I made this as directed except I used chicken broth instead of water, added onion to the vegetables. It was easy enough and an eye appealing Dish. Was I crazy about the taste? I would say it was O.K.I probably won’t make it again. Husband didn’t really rave about it.

I made several adjustments to this recipe, because I either couldn't find or didn't have several ingredients. Used a commercial Verde sauce, but added the chicken bullion. This really makes a difference and gives it great flavor. Also used shredded Mexican cheese blend at end and put it in the over for 30 minutes at 350 to melt and cook extra. It ended up great!
Delicious!

I've made this twice now and it was such a hit. The sauce is so good, if you have any left over you can save it and use it with other meals. The second time I made this I made two small changes, I used just a bit less water because the sauce is pretty watery. I also baked the assembled enchiladas for about 10 minutes at 425 just to make sure everything was good and hot. This might be one of my favorite recipes I've ever used from Allrecipes.

We enjoyed this dish so much! I baked the garlic, tomatillos and serrano peppers in a 400 degree oven til lightly browned. I substituted 3 cups of organic chicken broth for the chicken bouillon granules and 3 cups of water.

It's worth the effort to make your own sauce! These came out so good that we didn't have any leftovers. Use the full amount of Serrano peppers if you like a little heat. I only used 2 and it wasn't enough. I also added cilantro to the blender when I chopped the tomatillos and peppers.
Very delicious, would recommend to double or triple the recipe.

I'm Hispanic but only cook by recipe. I envy those that can cook by just eyeing it. Like my mother that just goes into the fridge and brings out a bunch of items and 30 mins later we have a great meal. I need to follow instructions (LOL).... Well I followed these instructions and it came out GREAT!!!!!! Going forward I will make the sauce ahead of time so that the following day I just have to just roll the tortillas. They do get a little cold especially since I'm a little slow. :) But I place them all in a casserole dish and then placed it in the oven for about 12mins. Cheese was melted added more sauce and Yummmmmm!!!!! Looking forward to making this again.
The original recipe is great! I added roasted pablano peppers to the shredded chicken the second time I made it and WOW.
I make this recipe with garlic and buttered shrimp instead and it is delicious!
This is a keeper.
Would be five stars but cooking the chicken at that temperature/amount of time makes it very tough and dry. I would try baking at 450 for 20-25 minutes instead

I may never go out to eat. These were amazing and super easy! It is pretty spicy and I only used two Serrano peppers but it was the perfect amount of heat for me. I will be making this again and again.
I add cilantro and cumin to mine, sometimes I add less water. The sauce is a little thin but I've been using this recipe for years and the others just don't compare. Delicious!!

This was amazing! I only replaced the serrano pepper with cubanelle, because my husband doesn't like spicy food (also, I was unable to find it). It was a hit!

For the folks complaining about how spicy it is, know your peppers! If you don't like spicy things, use a milder pepper.

10/10 Will make again.
My husband LOVES this dish. It is a little bit of work but so worth it.
I've made this a couple times as well as making the salsa separate for chips and dip. You won't be disappointed.

I just made this and it turned out great! However heading the words of other reviews I changes something things. I roasted the garlic, Serrano peppers and tomatillos. I only added 2 cups of water instead of three and instead of adding all 3 Serrano peppers I added one Seeded! And it was oleanty of heat! I thought even that would be to spicy but it turned out great! I used sour cream mixed with a little milk instead of Mexican crema and skipped the coja cheese just to be a little more wallet friendly. Still turned out awesome and I would make again!

I have made this recipe many times, and it always is a hit. It tastes fabulous. Make SURE to eat it right when it's done; don't let it sit around and then eat it because everything will go soggy. Sometimes it doesn't work well if you have to take it somewhere, because it may be soggy by the time it gets there.
Turned out awesome, I can't wait till hatch season to replace the peppers with hot hatch peppers

Love this recipe! I took other reviewers suggestions: I didn't fry the tortillas-- I used olive oil spray on both sides of the tortillas, placed them on a baking sheet and put them in a 350 degree oven for 10 minutes. Also, I put the tomatillos, serrano peppers, and garlic cloves in the broiler for 20 minutes versus charring them on the stove top. Please note: Start with two serrano peppers in the blender vs putting all three-- Two was enough heat for me!

Followed recipe exactly with one exception, I removed the seeds from the Serrano peppers prior to blending. I like hot food, but my daughter does not. This recipe was awesome! It was the perfect use of leftover rotisserie chicken. Next time I make it, I will split the sauce in two batches and make one spicy and one mild. Great recipe!

This was absolutely delicious. I did lower the salt a bit from other reviews but besides that it is a great recipe and taste just like the restaurants. I made it last week and am making it again tonight. Highly recommend it!

I too love Mexican food, one reason I have spent so much time vacationing, studying, visiting and backpacking there. I love street food, home cooked meals and formal restaurants. So after reading all the 5 star reviews I went out and bought all the ingredients. 

I used only one Serrano pepper; roasted, seeded and stemmed and the sauce was far to hot for company or even me.

While making the sauce I dipped my little finger in to see if I need to ad more peppers and threw the entire batch down the garbage disposal. Waste of money, waste of time and very disappointment.

It's got possibilities but too much work for a weeknight meal and not a home run. It was runny enough w/out athe 3 cups of water. Also not sure why use of store bought chicken was recommended. I would have also liked the tortillas crispier to add more crunch. I adhered to the 5 second per side since it was my first time making. Loved the authentic cheese, Mexican 'sour cream' and cilantro.

Sooooo good! and easy to prepare. One suggestion broil the tomatillos and garlic instead of doing it on the griddle it only takes a couple min. also if you want to cut calories cook your tortillas with cooking spray on a hot pan, to me they still taste like they've been deep fried. Gracias Gema! Elvira S.

I did this recipe to a tee and the sauce was so spicy it knocked my head off! I don't know if our store's serrano peppers just happen to be beyond spicy today or what!? I added a ton of honey and yogurt and chicken broth to try to tone it down and that didn't even work. I had to run to the store and buy store bought enchilada sauce. Also it's way too much mexican crema, I drizzled it and probably only used a quarter of it, as it would have been way too much. Also I put them in the oven at 350 for 30 minutes to melt the cheese a bit which was great. I will make again but with lots of little changes.
I made this with leftover turkey and added a roasted Poland to the sauce. They turned out great. Next time I will use grilled chicken and make extra sauce to use for a breakfast chilaquiles dish.
I just used green enchilada sauce from the can.

Like many others, I broiled my tomatillos garlic and peppers. I accidentally bought pablano peppers which are very mild so my salsa wasn't spicy at all. I fried flour tortillas instead of corn since we don't like corn tortillas and I used Monterey Jack cheese for the top. My husband said "this is the best meal you've ever made" I don't know how reliable he is though because he says that every time I cook lol ?? All in all great recipe! Yumms!

Not only were these delicious and fresh, they were easy to make! Way better than the American casserole style of enchilladas I was used to. I live in the middle of nowhere so I wasn't able to use the mentioned cheese, but finely shredded "Mexican blend" cheese worked just fine. Tomatillos is where its at!
This recipe is so good! I've made it a few times and every time it's amazing. I use the leftover sauce for eggs, potatoes, even as salsa - pretty much anything I can until it's gone.

Don't try this at home! We followed the recipe as closely as we could, the only changes we made were we used chicken breasts left over from a recent cookout, and we used plain greek yogurt for the crema because we couldn't find it at any market around here.

The end result was delicious, for sure. But we (my wife and I) had to make an assembly line to assemble everything at the end. It took us almost 2 hours to prepare. I had planned to have dinner ready when she got home, but there was no way I could have completed this alone and have it still be hot and fresh.

So I give it 4 stars because it has a truly wonderful flavor. But I will not make it again, because the ingredients are too hard to find, the kitchen was destroyed after I was done (too many bowls, pans, trays etc to clean up), and the sheer effort required to make it.
All my family love this recipe!!thank you

I made these yesterday for Cinco De Mayo, and my gosh!!! The best enchiladas ever! My whole family loved them and requested I make more yesterday (which I did) and they want more today. Thank you for sharing this recipe.
Great recipe! I won't make enchiladas any other way now that I have found this gem. I broiled the tomatillos, peppers and garlic and was able to finish making the dish in 30 minutes.

I think this recipe is great. Very much like my own recipe I use. For all who want to make it even better. I use home made corn tortillas when making enchiladas of any sort or tacos etc. but especially for green enchiladas. The other thing as for the chicken. I usually boil a whole chicken for the stock and shred the chicken for the enchiladas. I use the stock for the sauce and I use the left over stock for my Mexican rice instead of water. Its more work but I think the secret to any fantastic Mexican dish is using home made tortillas. Also if I can't make them we have a tortilla company here in town and I usually go and buy them warm there to use for our enchiladas.
This was VERY good! I put pico de gilo on top of mine instead of lettuce because we're not big on lettuce. Excellent! Thanks for sharing.
MMMMmmmm.....delicioso!!!
Best enchiladas ever. I was a little skeptical about the claims that one would desire to drink the sauce. Get yourself a glass, cause you will want to drink it.

LOVE!! I was actually looking for a recipe for Chile Verde when I came across this. And if I'm honest, I only use the sauce part of this recipe and it's amazing. We love it!! I use the verde sauce for making chile verde almost weekly. I adjust the garlic and serranos, more garlic and usually only 2 serranos. I don't have a griddle so I first used the broil setting in my oven then I started putting my tomatillos in the oven for around 20min first then adding my serranos and garlic and turning the broil on. Love the way the flavor comes out!! It's been amazing every time! I've actually got tomatillos on my counter now, I'll be making this tomorrow!
Delicious I followed the recipe to the letter. Everyone loved it.
This is awesome. Takes some time but really made a fabulous meal. Made as directed for the most part and everyone love it.

Amazing and delicious. The sauce seemed a bit watery to me so next time I won't use so much. I'm not a wimp when it comes to spice but I was worried about it being too spicy so I only used one Serrano pepper. I realize now I could have used all three. But if you're sensitive to spice stick with one. My husband was amazed and said it was better than any restaurant he's been to. Winning recipe!
I make a lot of enchiladas and these are my favorite green enchiladas. Highly recommend.
Great recipe! The amount of heat was just right for me, I can handle some but not crazy spicy. It will be too much for my husband so I think I'll decrease the number of serranos in it. Fantastic!

Amazing recipe. I have made this time after time and my family doesn't get tired. It's time consuming, but the end results are delicious. I kept everything the same except I used ground beef instead of chicken. Still delicious.

I enjoyed this recipe. Picked up the ingredients fairly easily at the local market. Wasn't difficult to make. Kids wouldn't have anything to do with it but my wife ate two helpings. Would have used one cup less water on the sauce. Definitely keep the Serrano seeds in to give it some spice.
Just made this recipe we used slow roasted pulled pork this is a winner!!

These are delicious! I didn't have the cheese listed so I used queso fresco crumbled on top. I used 2 serrano peppers to 1lb of tomatillos & used 1 1/2 cups of water to dilute the hotness of the serranos. My husband, who loves spicy foods, said it was the perfect balance. I didn't have the crema either but it didn't need it- the sauce is wonderful. Thank you for an easy, delicious meal!

Great sauce recipe. I used a store bought roasted chicken for more flavor. Feel like the recipe is missing something though, it's a little dry. Maybe so cheese or something rolled up with the chicken inside?
Excelente!

I made this for dinner tonight and my husband and I liked the spice. I used two Serrano peppers. It was too spicy for my small children though. We also used grated Parmesan and sour cream that was on hand. It was delicious and I will definitely make again.

I followed the recipe as much as I could, but couldn't locate crema fresca so used sour cream instead. The flavor was great, but my one complaint is that they were soggy. I think I'm used to the more traditional way we get them in restaurants so wasn't expecting that. I kept thinking they needed to go in the oven to crisp them up.
This recipe was exactly what I was looking for as far as authenticity. I didn't want to buy canned sauce.

This is hands down the best recipe I've made from this site. These enchiladas were authentic, easy to make and delicious. The only thing I did different from the recipe was to broil the ingredients instead of using the griddle. I left them in there until they were blackened which was about the same time as listed in the recipe. I dumped the juices the tomatillos left into the blender and used one less cup of water to compensate. Great recipe!
Loved these! I made them exactly as described in the recipe. I thought I didn't like verde sauce or corn tortillas (at least I have never liked either one in restaurants) but this dish was delicious.
Made this tonight I used a can of mushroom soup. And some homemade green salsa. And topped with pepper jack cheese. Also used cumin and extra galric salt.
